chemoreception.notes: Members of this family, exemplified by Trimusculus reticulatus, use chemoreception to detect predators like seastars. They release a mucus when attacked which is detected by the seastar.

mechanoreception.notes: Inferred through observation of defense mechanism: T. reticulatus responds to physical contact from seastars, suggesting the presence of mechanoreceptors to detect touch or pressure.

vision.notes: The presence and capabilities of vision in Trimusculidae are unknown based on the provided context.
